awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Carbon-Helium-Argon Isotope Relations at High-3He/4He Hotspots and Implications for Mantle Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon isotope ratios are a primary source of information for understanding the global carbon cycle, which has a role in the generation of greenhouse gases; the movement of carbon from Earth's surface back into its interior; and the escape to Earth's surface of primordial carbon that has been trapped deep in the planet since it formed 4.5 billion years ago. These isotope ratios, however, are impacted by a variety of geologic processes, such as the degassing of magma during volcanic eruptions. This causes fractionation that changes the original ratio of the isotopes, making them difficult to interpret fully.  Without some means of recognizing these changes, it is not possible to fully understand the cycle of carbon on Earth and the story it tells. One way to overcome the carbon isotope fractionation problem and get a handle on the amount and composition of carbon in the deep Earth is to look at the isotopes of noble gases that are erupted along with carbon dioxide (CO2) that comes out of volcanoes. Although we know a lot about carbon in shallow Earth reservoirs, its concentration, isotopic composition, and behavior in the deep mantle is not well understood. This research uses the content and isotopic composition of two noble gases: Helium (He) and Argon (Ar) from volcanic rocks at two locations in the Pacific (Hawaii and the Lau Spreading Center in the western Pacific), to unravel the story of carbon in the deep mantle and improve our knowledge of the carbon cycle, carbon fluxes, and carbon sources emanating from the Earth. Broader impacts of the research include laboratory and research training of a graduate student whose gender is underrepresented in the sciences; the training of undergraduates at an institution in Oklahoma, an institution in an EPSCoR (Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research) state; support of an NSF-funded state-of-the-art noble gas analytical facility in the state of Oregon; and incorporation of research results into courses. 

This research utilizes coupled measurements of He, Ar and CO2 abundances in both the vesicles and glasses of submarine basalts erupted at two different locations in the Pacific Ocean. One is Loihi seamount off the island of Hawaii and the other is the Lau Spreading Center, both of which have been influenced by the presence of mantle plumes that tap deep mantle regions. Measurements will include the concentration and isotopic positions of CO2, He, Ar, and H2O trapped in volcanic glasses and vessicles. Release of the gases takes place in a state-of-the-art noble gas laboratory at Oregon State University.  Gases in vesicles in the lavas will be released via crushing the lava in a vacuum. He and Ar concentrations and isotopic compositions in the glass will be released via step heating/fusion.  Dissolved CO2 and H2O in the glasses will be determined by FTIR (Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy).  These data will be used to deconvolute changes in the carbon isotopic composition resulting from magma degassing so the primordial and recycled components of the carbon in the samples can be determined. Key research questions being addressed include: (1) What are the values of CO2/3He and the carbon isotopic ratio in the source region of mantle plumes; (2) is primordial carbon preserved in the deep source of mantle plumes; and (3) what is the CO2 flux at mantle plume localities. Results of the work will be integrated into geodynamic models addressing the cycling of carbon and noble gases between Earth's surface and deep reservoirs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated submarine lavas erupted at Loihi Seamount in Hawaii and the NW Lau Spreading Center (NWLSC) / Rochambeau Rift (RR) region in the western Pacific. Loihi Seamount is a submarine volcano formed in the interior of the Pacific tectonic plate, while NWLSC/RR are oceanic spreading ridges influenced by the distal Samoa hotspot. Both localities are well known for the presence of high helium-3/helium-4 ratios (3He/4He) in their lavas that signify the presence of a deep, primitive mantle source region that has remained isolated over Earth history. This source region produces melts that are brought to Earth's surface by the Hawaiian and Samoan mantle plumes, respectively.  The outer surfaces of the submarine lava flows are rapidly cooled to glass during eruption into seawater. Our primary goal was to characterize the helium and carbon isotope compositions (carbon-13/carbon-12 ratio, expressed as δ13C) of the mantle source regions by analyzing basalt glasses from each area, and ultimately, to quantify the proportion of carbon recycled from Earth's surface by plate tectonics over geologic time vs. the proportion of carbon trapped since the Earth first formed (referred to here as primordial carbon).

Our work involved analyzing dissolved carbon dioxide and water concentrations in natural basalt glasses by Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy. Separate aliquots of glass were crushed in vacuum at Oregon State U to release gases trapped in bubbles which was then analyzed for helium and carbon dioxide concentrations and helium and carbon isotope ratios by mass spectrometry.  The powders recovered from crushing were subsequently analyzed for He concentrations and 3He/4He ratios in the glass (which represent the helium that was dissolved in the basalt melt). Through this combined approach, the results were used to evaluate chemical and physical processes that affected gas concentrations, gas ratios, and isotope ratio variations in the magma. Cl and S were analyzed in Loihi glasses by electron microprobe at U Tulsa to understand assimilation and degassing in the lavas that might have affected CO2.

In the NWLSC/RR area, we found that lower carbon/helium ratios tend to be associated with higher ∂13C and 3He/4He ratios, and that most of the observed variability can be explained by mixing between mantle plume material derived from Samoa plume and material subducted beneath the Tonga volcanic arc. The lowest δ13C values from the NWLSC/RR area are explained by preferential loss of 13C relative to 12C during early stages of bubble loss from the magma.

At Loihi Seamount, the most gas-rich basalts have δ13C values trapped in their bubbles that are identical to values found in earlier studies of carbon dioxide dissolved in Loihi hydrothermal fluids. This supports the idea that much of the hydrothermal carbon may be derived by direct degassing of Loihi magma, rather than by "stripping" from crystalline rock during fluid circulation through the porous crust of the volcano. Overall, Loihi basalts are shifted to higher δ13C values (by 0.5 to 3 per mil) than commonly found in mantle-derived magma. Loihi submarine lavas have also lost >95% of their initial carbon as evidenced by their concentrations of trace elements that behave as proxies for mantle-derived carbon. Despite this large amount of degassing, many of the lavas appear to have erupted with δ13C values that are not very different from their mantle source value because degassing predominantly followed a closed-system behavior, in which most of the gas bubbles remained in contact with the magma until they were lost during eruption. Geochemical modeling shows that the shift in the Loihi mantle source carbon isotope composition from typical mantle values may be explained by the presence of a very small fraction, less than 1% by mass, of tectonically recycled calcium carbonate (limestone) in the mantle plume source. It is unclear whether any additional water accompanied this carbonate.

The results of this project are important for understanding the geodynamic cycling of volatile species, such as carbon dioxide and water, between Earth's surface and its interior. We attempted to develop new constraints for discerning between primordial and recycled carbon in the deep mantle. Our study produced the most extensive data set of high-precision helium isotope, and water, carbon and carbon isotope ratios, with complementary data for trace elements, on the same basalt glasses from Loihi Seamount. These results are also valuable for guiding studies of mid-ocean ridge volatiles and elsewhere. Our work leveraged previously collected samples from U.S. and international expeditions. The data from our project are archived at EarthChem and are available online for students and teachers in their course work within a variety of disciplines, and for other scientists in their research.

The project supported all work at The University of Tulsa, thereby helping to improve the research competitiveness of Oklahoma, a National Science Foundation EPSCoR state. The project provided financial support of the laboratory and graduate students at Oregon State University.
